newsitem.title: UK: BP first-quarter results beat forecasts.
newsitem.headline: BP first-quarter results beat forecasts.

text.p: British Petroleum Co Plc on Tuesday reported first-quarter results well ahead of market forecasts, due largely to higher oil prices, increased volumes and cost reductions.
Net earnings before exceptional items rose by 19 percent to 755 million pounds ($1.2 billion) from 633 million a year ago. In dollar terms, earnings in the quarter rose by 27 percent.

BP shares rose strongly after the results, which beat expectations centred around 690 million pounds. Analysts noted that the performance was strong across BP's range of operations, as well as showing progress towards efficiency targets.
BP shares were up 24-1/2 pence at 728 pence in early afternoon after touching 732p after the results.

"The results are very good...better in every segment," said Dresdner Kleinwort Benson analyst Paul Spedding. "It's important to note that it's not just (higher) oil prices -- it's also refining and chemicals."

Fergus MacLeod, analyst at Natwest Markets, said the results reflected a good performance from the upstream oil and gas exploration and production division. But he said they also contained "better progress towards self-help objectives."

The company said its improving portfolio of assets, continuing focus on costs and reduced level of debt were lowering the impact of changes in prices and margins, and said progress towards achievement of medium term targets remained ahead of schedule.
BP Chief Executive John Browne has set a 1997 objective of achieving $300 million of underlying performance improvements from productivity gains and cost savings.
The company said higher oil prices and volumes led to a 24 percent increase in upstream earnings to a record 913 million pounds, a 32 percent rise in dollar terms.
